awd_titl_txt: Catalyst Project: Infusion of Data Expertise into Undergraduate Biology Curriculum
awd_abstract_narration:
Catalyst Projects provide support for Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU) to work towards establishing research capacity of faculty to strengthen science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) undergraduate education and research. It is expected that the award will further the faculty member's research capability, improve research and teaching at the institution, and involve undergraduate students in research experiences. Albany State University intends to infuse data science and computational analyses into its biology curriculum. The proposed curricular enhancements aim to incorporate teaching and learning strategies that support student’s ability to understand and interpret globally accessible biological data, which has the potential to increase student preparedness for STEM graduate programs or the workforce. 

This project adapts a unique curriculum framework for promoting Data Expertise in the Undergraduate Biology Curriculum (DEUBiC). The central hypothesis is that students with data expertise are better prepared and are qualified for the globally competitive computational science-intensive workforce, as developed through strategic evidence-based teaching and learning. The team at Albany State University will infuse selected existing courses with content for honing data expertise as well as design and offer new upper-level courses: Biological Instrumentation Technology, Advanced Computing Resources in Biology, and Computational Genomics. Students will engage in data intensive research both as course-based research projects, and as mentored senior research projects. Through the project-based experiences, students will transfer learning from new and infused courses to pose research questions, develop testable hypotheses and design appropriate experiments to test predictions. The assessment of scientific literacy, quantitative literacy, and strategic learning approach, if successful, will contribute a transferable blueprint that could be applied to undergraduate STEM education, with potential for impact among underserved communities, minorities and women.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The design of the Data Expertise into Undergraduate Biology Curriculum (DEUBiC) Catalyst Project was conceived as a conceptual model for developing data expertise for biology undergraduates, laden with student learning experiences in the curriculum framework, in the context of biological literacy and practice concepts, where learning experiences are aligned to quantitative literacy challenges of data flow, data analytics and data curation. Evidence-based learning strategies were implemented, to equip students as strategic learners, capable of appropriating learning strategies for overcoming the challenges of the discovery of biological information from multiple sources, for the analysis of complex biological datatypes and for posing research questions, developing testable hypotheses and designing appropriate experiments to evaluate predictions. 

Major Activities aligned to the design objectives included.  

(1) Infusion of 5 courses taken by Biology Majors with quantitative expertise. Specific quantitative modules were developed and integrated into the existing courses. Those modules were also taught as part of the existing courses, to Biology majors and accessed in comparison with other components of the courses. (2) Implementation of a Faculty Development Workshop that covered (a) Train the Trainers; (b) Statistical and Computational Biology; and (c) Bioinformatics (3) Faculty members were trained in these areas listed above. The faculty members were therefore equipped with the ability to both (a) create instructional content in the form of course modules; (b) teach the created contents; and (c) access the instructed contents; (4) Students' engagement in quantitative biology contents as infused into their courses by faculty. Students were taught quantitative and analytical biological concepts, with the opportunity for hands-on interaction with biological data. Courses were graded and the performances of students were compared singly and in association with other components of the course taught. 

Significant results because of the project implementation include: 

(1) 7 faculty members gained knowledge about quantitative biology that they did not have before the program implementation; (2) 4 faculty members developed and implemented quantitative biology modules in their existing courses; (3) 5 existing Courses were infused with quantitative biology modules, improved and ready to be continually taught to students; m(4) 57 Students (48 Biology/9 Forensic Science majors) appreciation and performance of quantitative infused contents; (5) 3 new courses with significant quantitative expertise were developed, yet to be implemented. 

Program (potential) Impacts

Our infused Biology courses are principally registered for and taken by Biology majors. Learning analytical techniques and having hands-on experience with managing and making sense of biological data is sacrosanct if we must produce the next generation of Biologists. The project contributes to the enhancement of the Biology program that continues to change and continues to accommodate quantitative capacities. Other life sciences (e.g. Forensic Science) and other health allied fields (e.g. Nursing) have quantitative data relevant components also. Our Biology program therefore offers Biology courses to both Biology majors and non-majors. Training students with data-relevant competencies curricular and resultant improved course offerings therefore could have an impact on developing the next generation of biologists and allied health professionals for future workforce. The implementation of the program also allowed us to look at Biology as a ?quantitative? program. Teaching biology, especially the courses infused (and potentially, at the teaching of the newly designed courses), allows the utilization and embracing of best practices amenable to teaching quantitative sciences (e.g. relevant software selection, relevant online platform selection, self-teaching by students, biology data wrangling) among others. Implementation of the program also has enabled the purchase and setup of dedicated computers for Bioinformatics and Computational Biology at our institution. The implementation of the program has also enabled the purchase of laboratory equipment that students and faculty can utilize to generate raw biological data for downstream analysis. Another department can also have access to this infrastructure, with capabilities adaptable to their disciplines. The ability to utilize analysis software is the bedrock for developing data and quantitative competencies in the life sciences. Therefore, faculty and students who have both gone through training and instruction respectively, can own these capacities, and utilize the transferred technology in other parts of their work and professional endeavors. The training of students with the improved curriculum in the infused courses contributes to the potential of building the next generation of biologists capable of fitting appropriately into the data-relevant and data-intensive future workforce.

 


Last Modified: 10/30/2023
Modified by: Olabisi O Ojo
